metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Respondent No. 1 (Hoshangabad Constituency Election)

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 5 nominated for election to the House of the People from Hoshangabad Constituency in Madhya Pradesh.
Respondents 4 and 5 withdrew from the election.
At polling, appellant secured 65,201 votes, first respondent 65,375 votes, other candidates far less; Returning Officer declared first respondent duly elected.

Appellant filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 to set aside election alleging 301 votes for first respondent liable to rejection under Rule 47(1)(c) of Act No. XLIII of 1951 for lacking distinguishing mark under Rule 28 (green bar for Parliamentary constituencies).

In polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 at Sobhapur, voters for House of the People given ballot papers with brown bar (for State Assembly) instead of green bar; total such votes 443: 62 for appellant, 301 for first respondent, rest for others.
First respondent contested petition, pleaded Rule 47 directory not mandatory, votes accepted as valid by Election Commission, defect cured.

First respondent filed recrimination petition under s.97 alleging at polling station No.299 at Malkajra and No.371 at Bammangaon, ballot papers for State Legislature wrongly issued for House of the People, wrongly rejected by Returning Officer; if counted, he would get 117 more votes than appellant.
Election Tribunal by majority held Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory, 301 ballot papers should have been rejected, but unanimous that result not materially affected under s.100(2)(c); dismissed petition.
Appellant moved High Court of Nagpur under Arts.226 and 227 for certiorari to quash Tribunal decision as illegal and without jurisdiction.
High Court Bench (Sinha CJ, Mudholkar J, Bhutt J) differed but majority dismissed petition; granted certificate under Art.132(1).
Returning Officer at Hoshangabad obtained approval from Election Commission before counting for including wrong ballot papers due to polling officers' mistake.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Courts have jurisdiction under Art.226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals, given Art.329(b).
Whether Tribunal becoming functus officio bars certiorari under Art.226.
Whether Rule 47(1)(c) is mandatory or directory.
Whether result of election materially affected under s.100(2)(c) by improper reception of votes under Rule 47(1)(c), considering polling officer's mistake under Rule 23.
Scope of enquiry under s.100(2)(c) and effect of recrimination under s.97.

petitioner_arguments.text: 301 ballot papers for first respondent lacked distinguishing mark under Rule 28, liable to rejection under mandatory Rule 47(1)(c); excluding them, appellant would have largest votes; result materially affected.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 47(1)(c), Rule 28, s.100(2)(c) of Act No. XLIII of 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court has jurisdiction under Arts.226/227 to issue certiorari against Tribunal; Tribunal erred in considering irrelevant matters like polling officer mistake for s.100(2)(c) enquiry.
Enquiry under s.100(2)(c) limited to election petition; no complaint of Rule 23 breach.

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 47(1)(c) directory not mandatory; Returning Officer rightly accepted votes; Election Commission validated them.
No jurisdiction under Art.226 due to Art.329(b); Tribunal functus officio.

Result not materially affected; consider polling officer mistake under Rule 23, chain of breaches; ascertain voter intention; recrimination shows similar breaches at other stations giving 117 extra votes.

court_reasoning.text: Art.329(b) bars initiation of proceedings questioning election except by election petition; once petition decided by Tribunal, supervisory jurisdiction under Art.226 applies to quash erroneous decisions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.329(b) limited to initiation; post-Tribunal decision open to certiorari.

court_reasoning.text: Certiorari to quash directed at record, not tribunal; can issue to custodian of record even if Tribunal functus officio (s.103 directs records to District Judge/Chief Judge Small Causes).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Destructive remedy wipes out order; no need for ongoing tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory like other sub-rules (a,b,d); no degrees of compliance in rejection; Election Commission condoned specific papers but did not change prescribed mark under Rule 28; approval post-polling invalidates nothing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Shall be rejected' mandatory; cannot accept wrong mark due to polling error.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.100(2)(c), first condition satisfied (improper reception); but for material effect, cannot count rejected votes or speculate on voter intention beyond formalities; Tribunal erred considering Rule 23 breach to validate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Result means on valid votes per Rule 48; Tribunal cannot accept what RO must reject.

court_reasoning.text: Recrimination under s.97 shows appellant's hypothetical election also void for Rule 23 breach; no valid election; quash Tribunal, set aside election.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.97 bars declaring petitioner elected if his would be set aside.

holdings.text: High Courts have jurisdiction under Art.226 to issue certiorari against Election Tribunal decisions notwithstanding Art.329(b).
Certiorari available even if Tribunal functus officio.
Tribunal erred on face of record in s.100(2)(c) by considering extraneous matters; both elections invalid.

precedents_cited.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.329(b) covers entire election process; bars original proceedings under Art.226.
Post-Tribunal, Art.136 appeal possible; parity for Art.226 certiorari.

precedents_cited.case_name: T. C. Basappa v. T. Nagappa
precedents_cited.relevance: Nature of certiorari: supervisory, quashes without substituting; error on face of record.
Art.227 superintendence over Tribunals judicial and administrative.
Mandatory rejection for identification marks; ballot secrecy.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (Act No. XLIII of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs election petitions, ballot validity, rejection rules, material effect test, recrimination.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction vs. election bar; certificate for appeal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court and Tribunal decisions quashed by certiorari under Art.226; election of first respondent set aside under Art.227; both parties' hypothetical elections invalid due to s.97 recrimination; Election Commission to hold fresh election.
outcome.relief_granted: Election set aside; fresh poll directed

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution no election shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as may be provided for by or under any law made by the appropriate Legislature." (Art.329(b))
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits to initiation of election challenges.

key_quotes.text: A writ of certiorari to quash is directed against the record; fact that tribunal functus officio has no effect.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Rule 47(1)(c) is mandatory... There can be no degrees of compliance so far as rejection is concerned."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The result of the election in s.100(1)(c) means the result on the basis of the valid votes.
key_quotes.speaker: court
